Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 4c36c12a2b07115610179b8805480bbbc55034a0
New patches are not allowed.  Please refactor so that this can be applied as an option to the original scripts if necessary.
You mention optimsation and speed but there are no comparative numbers provided. Can you please demonstrate the improvement with evidence in the commit message?
You should split this into a separate change
We should just validate these are never in one of these paths in the `bb` file? You really don't want to find out at runtime.
yeah good point, this check is copied from obmc-update.sh we could change that as well. Hopefully no one is editting this list in runtime
The `whitelist` doesn't need to be a parameter, it's not a parameter to the update script either

You will want to to remove directories too, I don't think it needs to restrict the find to specific types, it always traverses down before the top level directory containing the files, so it should be safe to use `-delete` for dirs too.
I was trying that but cannot find a good way. the prune does not play too well with dir. E.g. if you prune /a/b/c/d. /a/b/c will still show up in the result and you don't want to clear that dir.

This was my original change that I believe handles those cases, instead of trying to prune things out of the path it just wildcards whitelist entires and then has explicit allowed paths for all directories about a whitelist entry

```
do_clean_rwfs_quick() {
        mount $rwdev $rwdir -t $rwfst -o $rwopts || return
        st=$?
        args="-mindepth 1"
        while read -r l; do
                l=".$l"
                args="$args ! -path $l/*"
                while [ "$l" != ./ -a "$l" != . ]; do
                        args="$args ! -path $l"
                        l="$(dirname $l)"
                done
        done </run/initramfs/whitelist                     
        args="$args -print -delete"
        (cd $rwdir/cow; echo "$args" | xargs find . || st=$?)
        umount $rwdir || st=$?
        return $st
}
```
oh this looks feasible for clearing dir as well. The args will be floated a bit but I think that won't affect the performance too much. Let me test and see.
Yeah, you get n+1 args per component in a whitelist path. But it's only growing with the size of that list and not the files in the FS.
done, -delete is not available on some busybox find and replaced with rm -rf {} +
Do we even want to make this an option? If we do, probably make it the default.
You probably want to make it fall back to traditional clearing if the fast clear fails.

Can we canonicalize this in the build too? Drop any /./ or /../ or /. or //?

Probably just use `realpath -L -m $path` in the build to clean up all of these things. Or just error if `realpath -L -m $path != $path` so that we can ensure the list is simply formatted.

Maybe I can just filter out those stuff.

realpath is tricky since that it will derive the path link, so if a file happens to be a link in the local env then it will failed
Well I guess I can just append ${WORKDIR} before the path.
Probably `-exec rm -rf {}` is slower than just using `-delete`?
-delete is not available in all versions of find (also not in our version). It should be fine as the "+" version will minimize the cmd call time and the performance looks still good in my test.

My personal preference is to use braces when concatenating things this way:

```
l="${1}${l}"
```

Also the adjacent-ish `1` and `l` makes for poor reading 😞 Can we choose a better name? like, 'entry', or `elem`?

Also, why reassign back into `$l`? We're transforming the value, surely the value means something different now? It looks like `$1` is the path to the mount point, and we're making the whitelist path absolute? Can we give it a name that reflects that?

There's also no validation that `${1}` contained a trailing `/` for the path concatenation.

${1} shouldn't need to contain the trailing slash as ${l} does have a preceeding slash always, which is a guarantee of the absolute path validation.

Yeah, `l` is `line` but is especially bad when paired directly with `1`

Changed 'l' to 'line'.

The inner loop is to add all parent path to the find command as well. e.g., a whitelist entry /a/b/c will generates ! path /a/b/c/* ! path /a/b/c ! path /a/b ! path /a. Otherwise the parent dir will be removed and that is not what we want.

I added a comment as well and hopefully it can make things more clear.

> ${1} shouldn't need to contain the trailing slash as ${l} does have a preceeding slash always, which is a guarantee of the absolute path validation.

Good point.
Why do this here? This seems to be mixing concerns.
It's a straightforward way to append arguments to find below, the `-exec rm -rf {}` or `-delete` need to go at the end.
Yeah okay. I didn't think that through enough.
Can you add a comment with an example invocation of this line? I feel that will help readers comprehend the logic above.
